body:
Hello @Mottl! Thanks for updating the PR.



 - In the file [`pandas/tests/frame/test_analytics.py`](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/a2b71008a4e6e5176e89f6cdc2cf3172a0ed31e8/pandas/tests/frame/test_analytics.py), following are the PEP8 issues :

> [Line 471:46](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/a2b71008a4e6e5176e89f6cdc2cf3172a0ed31e8/pandas/tests/frame/test_analytics.py#L471): [E231](https://duckduckgo.com/?q=pep8%20E231) missing whitespace after ','

> [Line 472:55](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/a2b71008a4e6e5176e89f6cdc2cf3172a0ed31e8/pandas/tests/frame/test_analytics.py#L472): [E231](https://duckduckgo.com/?q=pep8%20E231) missing whitespace after ','

> [Line 483:63](https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/a2b71008a4e6e5176e89f6cdc2cf3172a0ed31e8/pandas/tests/frame/test_analytics.py#L483): [E226](https://duckduckgo.com/?q=pep8%20E226) missing whitespace around arithmetic operator



##### Comment last updated on December 25, 2018 at 11:53 Hours UTC
what is the utility of this? we are loathe to add additional api

@jreback
The utility is simple:  
during the feature selection process it is not desirable to spend time to get a full correlation matrix when the number of features is huge. It's more important to calculate a correlation matrix between M number of features and Y number of targets (we have a variety of different targets and we want to understand how features correlate to each of them) and `corrmatrix()` makes it simple.

So `corrmatrix()` is a simple form of `corr()` but without unnecessary calculations which will be dropped anyway.

This is how most people solve this problem:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34896455/how-to-do-pearson-correlation-of-selected-columns-of-a-pandas-data-frame
viewed: 24,989 times!

They calculate the full correlation matrix and drop all the unnecessary columns or make a lambda function, but it works only for correlation between DataFrame and Series, not with two DataFrames.

-1 on this api as it will make things even more confusing
@jreback, how about adding new param to the existing `.corrwith()` function to compute all pair correlations between DataFrames instead of name-like?
@Mottl would be more ameanable to an extension to an existing method. though pls put up an example of what you want to do with copy-pastable code (and the 'work-around')

We could add the `which` param to `DataFrame.corrwith()` method.
`which='same'` for the current behaviour (returns a Series with pair-wise correlations between columns or rows with the same name/index)
`which='all'` to produce a correlation matrix (returns a DataFrame with pair-wise correlations between columns (or rows) of all possible combinations)

Example:
```python
 index = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd', 'e']
 columns1 = ['one', 'two']
 columns2 = ['three', 'four']
 df1 = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(5, 2), index=index, columns=columns1)
 df2 = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(4, 2), index=index[:4], columns=columns2)
 df1.corrwith(df2, which='all')
```
@jreback, what are we doing with `df1.corrwith()`? Changing as I described above?
can u show the output of your example above with both options

@jreback

```python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
df1 = pd.DataFrame({'a':np.random.randn(10), 'b':np.random.randn(10)})
df2 = pd.DataFrame({'a':np.random.randn(10), 'c':np.random.randn(10)})

df1.corrwith(df2)  # default, which='same'
```
```
a    0.40657
b        NaN
c        NaN
dtype: float64
```
```python
df1.corrwith(df2, which='all')  # new
```
```
          a         c
a  0.406570 -0.005083
b -0.231165 -0.318797
```

@Mottl ok I think adding a parameter ``how='pairwise|all'`` might be ok here.

cc @jorisvandenbossche
@jreback, what should I do with the cancelled Circleci jobs? Is the PR well enough since Travis is green?
i cancelled those jobs
I know

> @Mottl ok I think adding a parameter `how='pairwise|all'` might be ok here.
> cc @jorisvandenbossche

@jreback, @jorisvandenbossche
please review
conceptually this might be ok, but I think you have killed performance for the common case. Can you show the asv's.?

```python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
df1 = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(1000,30))
df2 = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(1000,30))

%timeit df1.corrwith(df2)
23 ms ± 1.52 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each)

%timeit df1.corrwith_orig(df2)
34.7 ms ± 2.17 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each)
```

Actually, the **new implementation is 34% faster** than the old one since it uses `pd.Series.corr()` which in turn uses numpy's `corrcoef()` instead of `left - left.mean()`, `right - right.mean()`, etc.
try with a large number of columns

Same — **33% faster**:
```python
df1 = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(10000,3000))
df2 = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(10000,3000))

%timeit df1.corrwith(df2)
5.7 s ± 81.3 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1 loop each)

%timeit df1.corrwith_orig(df2)
8.45 s ± 152 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 1 loop each)
```

@jreback 
Please, review
can you merge master and update to comments.

@jreback 
merged

@jreback
Let's do the things simpler — just fix what you want.

@Mottl the point is that the community does these PRs
if you don’t want to complete then close this
